reviewDescription: The good, they sound amazing while they work and stay connected.The bad is pretty much everything else.- poor packaging, hard to cleanly find all the bits an pieces in case you ever want to start, send back or give to someone- charging case like it was designed by completely different UX team at Sony, no rechargeable, cheap pin/button to snap shut or open- not as small or comfy as they appear- yet another piece of software to install on my phone for full feature set- but worst of all they won't stay connected to. my phone, constant brown outs

Despite claims of being very comfortable and secure... they weren't. Yes, I tried every rubber tip. Maybe my ears just aren't shaped for these. They always felt like they would fall out after some head-shaking...

The sound is nice open back is uncommon but welcome on these type of device. I disabled media management in the app, but still these Bluetooth device are pausing arbitrarily my media playback. Would be great otherwise.

I loved the design. The open back sound in  bud is a great idea. I thought the sound quality was fine. But I really wanted to use them for calls, so that I can get natural feedback while talking. Problem is the battery life. I had two pairs and neither could keep going to over 2 hours. It's a shame. Everything else was good, but for the money, I wanted them to be executed better

reviewTitle: too big for my ears. eats hurt after wearing for some time
reviewDescription: Overall, cool idea, but headphones are too big even with the smallest ear tip and my ears hurt after some time. Can't use :'(

Edit at the end!TL;DR : After 13 months (warranty of 12 months), this 250$ pairs of earbuds is basically thrash.The right bud sounds like the driver is busted, and the left bud has always had trouble charging in the case (the clip inside the case doesn't hold on tigh to the earbud so it sometimes doesn't charge or register like the bud has been taken out of the case, so there are problems pairing as well).I find it so bad that a 250$ piece of tech doesn't have more than a year of warranty.The sound was good due to open back design, but comfort will depend from person to person since it depends on your ear shape. For me the right one is super confy but the left hurts if i wear it for more than a couple hours.I would not recommend this product and unless sony cha ges its warranty, I won't be buying from them anymore. 13 months of use for a busted driver is unforgivable, especially since i always use at low volume (use in public or before going to sleep).Edit : after 18 months or so of use, the right bud not only sounds like a busted driver, it wont hold charge properly. It will randomly loose charge and drain case battery overnight, even when plugged in. For all that is good and fair in this world, do not buy this product.

We purchased these in March.  I primarily wear them walking the dog, so the open-ear design was perfect for not blocking out traffic noise.The microphone quality is fantastic.  This is the first pair of earbuds I’ve owned that I’ve been able use for conversations with my elderly father.  Other earbuds pick up too much background noise, or create an echo that makes it hard for him to hear me.Unfortunately, after 9 months they are toast.  The speaker portion has separated, and while it fits back together now there is a buzzing in that ear.  When I contacted Sony for warranty, I was initially told by the agent that it’s “cosmetic” damage.  Then I was told that the warranty only covers the software, despite the warranty itself reading “This limited warranty covers only the hardware components packaged with the product.”  To add insult to injury, it was suggested that I drop them off for authorized repair at a store in Ontario (I am in Alberta).I admit that these have seen daily use.  I was ridiculously happy with them.  But I’m highly unlikely to spend another $300 on a pair of earbuds that don’t last a year, and won’t have the warranty honoured.  I’ve had significantly cheaper options that lasted for years with the same use.

Garbage tbh, they only connect to my android phone. They fail to pair on windows 11. If you manage to pair, it isn't actually paired and will silently disconnect from them if they appear to connect after pairing. No amount of setting changes works. I will likely return these as they do not work.Other gripes, the buttons are overly small, the lid is not spring loaded at all so good luck even getting the case open.

reviewTitle: These were perfect - until they deteriorate and distorte
reviewDescription: These were the perfect outside running/walking earbuds (5 stars!), and I’m so sad that with two different pairs, the audio drivers eventually began to distort…seems to be a flaw in their driver glues - or the driver materials - I think? Analog audio distortion, like a blown speaker.When exposed to sweat, perhaps (?), the drivers deteriorate and then start to distort. First pair lasted 2 months - used only during walks - then the left bud started to distort.Under warranty, they were replaced, and after using for about 10 walks, on humid summer days, the right driver on the new pair is now distorting. This is too bad, as otherwise, they were perfect - but clearly a design flaw.If you want these for running - or exercise - be aware that they will probably deteriorate and start distorting…at least that’s what happened to me.
Disappointed with fit and that Bluetooth was spotty.  Returned for full refund

The interesting design of these earbuds attracted me to them. I enjoyed using them until while riding my bike a strong gust of wind blew my left earbud out of my ear and into a nearby canal. It was lost in the water. 1. Ordering a replacement earbud costs the same price as ordering a new pair. 2. Pairing the earbuds to my new phone is IMPOSSIBLE because the left earbud is required to pair a new device. This seems like a pretty critical design flaw. What a waste of $200. I'm not planning to buy anything from Sony again.

reviewTitle: uncomfortable and not worth the money
reviewDescription: no matter how you put them in your ears, it hurts after five minutes of wearing them. feels like they're stretching out your ears. on top of this, the sound quality is bad. i thought they would be perfect for me because i like to be in tune with my surroundings - the concept of being able to hear the music as if it was apart of the rest of my environment was good in theory. it just didn't live up to my expectations, especially with how much they cost. airpods are cheaper and they work 10 times better than these

reviewTitle: Does not fit my ears. Also arrived used when the product was suppose to be new
reviewDescription: To my surprise, when I received my Linkbuds they were visibly used and already named / paired to another device when I attempted to pair them. Considering the retail price vs the used price, this is just upsetting and not something Amazon should allow. Don't know who's to blame for that screw up. Regardless, I cleaned them and gave them a try and they just don't fit my ears at all. Too bad because I was really hoping to have a more open back style earbud.
Don't buy

The case stopped charging after 15 days. Now the earbuds are dead. It was nice while it was working. However, I still prefer the Samsung Livebuds (Bean). I think it works better and the fit is similar. I am going to return it today.

These earbuds are amazing and have a lot of potential, but they aren't going to fit everyone. It includes 5 sizes for the "wing tip" on the back of the earbuds, yet none of the sizes properly fit my ears. I'm somehow about halfway between the small and medium size - small is too small and falls out, medium is too large and pops out. Even just smiling displaces them in my ears, so exercising or jogging in them would be impossible.For the short period of time they're in my ears before falling out, they're terrific. They're probably the most comfortable earbuds I've ever used, the "open" design works perfectly and I could hear everything around me as if I wasn't wearing earbuds, and sound quality is amazing for wireless earbuds. There's almost no bass, because of the design, but they have a much more open and wider soundstage than any wireless earbud I've used before. Plus mids are good and highs are clear. I find the positives more than make up for the lack of bass, but that's just my preference (I mainly listen to rock and alternative, so little ti no bass isn't the end of the world for me. Just means kick drums don't have much of an oomph to them). I did tweak the equalizer settings in the Sony app and tune it to what sounded best to me - audio quality right out of the box with a flat eq isn't anything special.I wanted earbuds to pair with my Samsung galaxy watch 4 for jogging specifically, but wanted ones that don't directly go inside my ear canals. That means my options boiled down to these, or the galaxy buds live. So I got both to see which one I liked better. To directly compared them:Fit: the Buds Live fit me significantly better than the Linkbuds do, but this is subjective and won't be the same for everyone. I can shake my head as hard as I possibly can and the Buds don't budge an inch. Meanwhile smiling makes the Linkbuds fall out. Two areas the Linkbuds do win here, though, are comfort and putting them in properly. I found the Linkbuds far more comfortable to wear for short periods than the Live. I couldn't test long term comfort because of how easily the Linkbuds fall out of my ears, though. The Linkbuds are also easier to put in your ears the "correct" way, meanwhile I still sometimes struggle to put the Buds properly in which leads to muffled audio until I adjust them into the correct position.Sound quality: the Linkbuds easily win in this category. The Buds have mildly more bass (we're talking 2.5/10 vs 1/10), but mids, highs, and the soundstage are all much better on the Linkbuds.Build quality: for the earbuds, the Linkbuds win by a mile. The earbuds themselves just feel so much higher quality, I much prefer the matte plastic used over the glossy plastic of the Buds. I also like the donut design more than the bean Buds, and the Linkbuds are also physically smaller which I like. In terms of the cases, though, the Buds win. The plastic in the Linkbuds case also feels nicer to the touch, and it uses a physically latch to open and close which is nice, but the Buds case supports wireless charging (the Linkbuds case does not) which is a huge advantage to me. The Buds also magnetically slide into their proper place, the Linkbuds need to be "clicked" into place or they won't charge. Lastly the Buds case has a larger battery which means more recharge time before depletion.Features: this one's a toss up. Wireless charging in the case is a pretty big one for me, in favour of the Buds, but the Linkbuds have a fully adjustable eq which is a massive (the Buds have multiple preset equalizers, no custom eq'ing). The open design of the Linkbuds also works significantly better than the transparency mode on the Buds. The Buds Live do feature active noise cancelling, but it's a joke and barely does anything at all. Lastly I have both a Samsung phone and smartwatch, so the Buds Live do automatically switch between devices for me. It's nice to have, but I have Sony XM4 headphones for my phone and only use the Buds with my Galaxy Watch, making the feature not especially useful. Both earbuds support some kind of "360 audio" but I didn't care for either implementation.Conclusion: If the Linkbuds had properly fit me, I would've chosen them over the Buds Live. But, because they fall out every 30-60 seconds, they were completely useless and all of their benefits and comparison wins were meaningless. I had no choice but to go with the Buds Live. Ended up returning the Linkbuds after only two days.

TL;DRYou think you want the features of these earbuds, but you probably don't. They try to solve some real issues but fall short on delivering a complete package.The Good- comfortable- stable- openThe BadThese are practically unusable outdoors. You will quickly realize why the most popular earbuds have all the tech that they do. It's fine to hear the outdoors, but they should have added some form of noise suppression, sort of how they do on the mic. Is the road work nearby? Forget about it. The irony is that the sound can be quite decent in perfectly quiet scenarios, but there is no way you will ever really get into your music. With these limitations, LinkBuds are just glorified Bluetooth ear pieces from the days gone by. Their main use boils down to work from home or the office. They're simply inadequate as a general purpose earbuds, especially at these prices.

These were amazing earbuds. Perfect, I'd even say for my use case, up until just a month or two ago when they stopped charging properly and the battery life was depleted to maybe 30min of use on my left ear. I hope Sony can fix this via firmware update but this has been a let down. Otherwise though, please Sony, don't give up on this concept of earbuds.

They work fine.  Battery life is fine - the case runs out quick, but the buds themselves last several hours, and it's easy enough to charge the case while using them.They don't stay in my ear very well no matter which ear loops I use, and this is especially true when talking - they wiggle out as my jaw moves.I also had to turn off the wide area tapping feature, because too often it would register jaw movements (like eating) as taps, and so my podcasts/music would pause, or skip around, at seemingly random moments.  Turning that off helped, but eating still occasionally triggers it (though that seems to have improved a bit after a recent firmware update, so at least they're working on it).The "talk to pause" feature worked well, but again - just normal jaw movements could accidentally trigger it, so I had to turn it off.The main reason I got them is because earbuds that actually go into your ear canal a bit bother me - these are much more comfortable, so I'm happy to tolerate the minor nuisances, most of which seem to be the type of thing that might be solvable with firmware updates, so I'm hopeful that they will get better.The right earbud has developed a slight buzzing after I cleaned them with isopropyl alcohol - that's probably my fault, the IPA probably damaged an O ring or something, but there were no warnings against using IPA for cleaning them, and IPA is generally the go-to for cleaning electronics. Just be aware.

reviewTitle: I want to love it, but it doesn't fit in me ear
reviewDescription: I appreciate Sony try new ideas of making this product. I love this open design. It's very small and light. The sound quality is Very good!The talk to chat is excellent.I gave it 3 Stars because two major issue,1. It doesn't fit in my ears.2. Small battery, and material feels cheap at this  price range.The battery is 5 hour, which is shy comparing with other earbuds at this price range. However, it could be a great choice for running because of the open design is a safty feature, you hear more environment.Very unfortunately, the unique shape doesn't fit in my ears. I have tried all different wings, and learn how to wear them without mirror. My ear hurts. Can't enjoy it.Look forward to seeing a new open design from Sony.

reviewTitle: Its not bad. It's also not amazing.
reviewDescription: I got this because all other earphones that need to be inserted in the ears cause inflammation for me.So I wanted an alternative that would be less intrusive.Audio quality is good and its easy to store and or bring with you.But the phone connection is very weak.I can't use it outdoors without having some chopped moments with it.Even with the phone on my pockets.Very often during those connection choppiness moments the earphones get misaligned and the left side starts playing the music with a 1 second delay. Enough to make it unusable unless I disconnect and reconnect again.Its ok for calls and use indoors, otherwise those are very weak and for this price it's hard to recommend.

Its fits perfectly. And sounds great. Its good when you have children. You can listen to music and to your surroundings. Safety first. No muffled sound. No ear irritations. Design looks cool too. The only thing is, i bought it from AMAZON WAREHOUSE SALE  for a better discount and it says LIKE NEW, and its in prestine condition. But when i got it, upon checking it, it was dirty!!! I had to clean it with alcohol. I want to send it back because of it. Why would they sell it in that condition? If it says USED, GOOD CONDITION, i wouldnt buy it. Amazon have to be more honest. Shame!

reviewTitle: Good idea but the fit is not my ears.
reviewDescription: I’m a big Sony fan, I have the c500 and the xm4I tried these out for the idea of the open back.My ears are pretty different from each other so usually the tips are different. Since these you can not change the size I was unable to comfortably wear the right earbud.Never the less it was a good idea, but personally for me the fit was not good, my right was way to small and it was extremely uncomfortably. Remember these are plastic and if they are just slightly to tight it just hurts.The sound was alright, but I’m sure it would sound better to some one who’s ear fit these fit perfectly.Id recommend trying them to see if they fit.

Overall I only like them , I don’t love them, they are comfortable and I don’t feel them at all ( I took the time to fit them properly)  , I can hear everything around me I really love hearing the ambient noise around I do however feel the battery does not last long and I don’t have a lot of the battery life using feature activated, I get about 4 hours of continuous use and during a 12 hour work shift the buds will die twice and the case once , other then the comfortable of these I don’t feel they are worth the price of them

reviewTitle: Great sound and light weight but battery is bad
reviewDescription: Great sound and light but the battery does not last that long, I am not sure if it's something to do with the settings but it just lasts maybe an hour.

reviewTitle: No footsteps sound when walking or running
reviewDescription: Got these yesterday and so far I love them. Finally solve my problem of pain in ear canal  and footsteps resonance.Summary & Straight to the point :These are pretty much useless in a very loud place like on the subway or next to very loud noise. They are open shape and have no Active Noise Cancellation (which would be useless anyway)If this is your case, look elsewhere.BUT they are light, comfortable, holds well and do not have the issue that most other earbuds have when blocking your ear canalAmazing!! :)In normal sound environment, like on the street, at work or at home, the sound level (for me) is great.Bass.. Ok but again, open design.Review :These are AMAZING if you are sensitive to footsteps when you walk, jogg or run. Any other pair of earbuds that I own and go in the ear canal creates a seal and, while they have better sound quality and deeper bass, the pressure is really annoying and every footsteps resonate all the way in my head.These Sony LinkBuds do not do that, they do not create this pressure and are very very light and confortable to wear.I gave 4 stars because if the earbuds deserve a 5 out of 5, the case is flimsy, feels very very cheap and diserve a 2 out of 5.The case belongs with a 40$ pair of earbuds. The plastic looks like it's going to crack just by looking at it, the hinges feels like it's going to break every time I open it.Hope this review helps.

These are sort of a mixed bag. I didn't buy/preorder these right after seeing it featured on LTT's Shortcircuit... yep.The bad:1. Battery life - put simply, they're not very good. Sony advertises up to 5.5 hours per charge. In my experience however, they took 2.5 hours to go from fully charged to 20% at around 50% volume. That's even worse than Sony's WF-1000XM3's (which I also own).2. Audio quality OR stable connection - setting the LinkBuds to prioritize audio quality results in the sound output being fairly close to the WF-1000XM3's, but at the expense of frequent connection dropouts. Setting them to prioritize connection quality makes them sound marginally worse.3. With the "Wide Area Tap" feature enabled, the LinkBuds have an unfortunate tendency to interpret jaw movement as taps. I was eating a burger, so my fingers were nowhere near my ears - yet the music kept pausing and restarting, because the LinkBuds thought I was double-tapping via my jaws...4. The default setting for Speak-to-chat is a little too sensitive for me. I had to set it to Low to avoid unnecessarily pausing audio all the time.5. There is no user configurable option to customize double/triple taps to perform functions that are different from the various presets offered in the app.6. No wireless charging on the case.The good:1. Fit - Of the five wingtip sizes, I have to use the XL wingtips to prevent them from falling out. If my ears are any larger I'd have no choice but to return them. Once they're fitted in my ears, though, they're more secure than the WF-1000XM3's, with none of the discomfort that all but stopped me from using those high-end TWS.2. "Open" back - the LinkBuds do not block or cancel external sounds. I don't have to turn on "transparency mode" or hold my hand over my ear (or earcup) in a weird way, just to be aware of the surrounding environment.3. Audio quality - I did write that they sound marginally worse when the LinkBuds are set to prioritize connection quality. Truth be told, they're not all that bad, especially considering the speaker design and the total absence of noise cancellation.4. Size - The LinkBuds case is thicker than the OG Apple AirPods (yes, I still have them!) while being slightly smaller on width/length. At the same time, it's almost HALF the size of the WF-1000XM3's. These are easily pocketable.Would I recommend the LinkBuds to anyone? No. They are TWS, yes, but the similarities stop beyond that, because these are TWS with the inherent disadvantages of open-back headphones. Battery life is not good, there's no sugarcoating it.Then why should I rate these 4 stars instead of 3? Simple. The vast majority of TWS on the market are closed-back, many of them with eartips and active noise cancellation. If I want a conventional TWS I can just buy some Samsung "Beans". The LinkBuds are open-back TWS, more open than AirPods, without the bone conduction tech that is otherwise mandatory this side of Bluetooth headphones. It's easier to rate highly when the choices are more limited, as is the case here.

I have had these for a long time now and I wear them almost everyday. Honestly, I can't find too many flaws with them. If you are looking at them I am guessing the open back is the reason why, at least it was for me. At max volume I can't have a conversation but still hear louder sounds like car horns ,loud screams ,loud exhaust etc..  when lowering the volume I can have a full conversation with music playing. Sound quality is good for the price not amazing studio quality but it's fine since that's not what they are aiming to be anyway. Comfort for my ears is actually amazing. I almost can't feel them at all when place properly ( I would say my ears are pretty big in terms of earbuds wearing at least). Over all they are my Daly drivers. I use them at least 1h a day and I have never once ran out of batteries on them and I plug the case only about every 2 days
Il son bon juste sa pren un temp pour les configurer et les mise à jour le son et bon mait pour marcher si c'est pour faire du sport il tombe

I'm not gonna write this like most of the essays that are here.The link buds are great if they fit your ears (as they did mine).If you like bass, stay away from these because the physics of the driver are not in your favor (although it is rather clean bass, for whatever little bass it has).Wide area tap is phenomenal.Wished there were more controls.Is surprisingly wide sounding, but the openness makes it somewhat expected.All in all, a good bud.Reason I am giving it 3 stars is because mine came with a factory defect on the left bud. Bass frequencies from 20hz to around 200hz make it produce a buzzing noise that is actually distracting in some genres of music (like hip hop, metal and such).Considering most people and reviewers didn't complain about this issue, I'm sure it's no big deal and I got unlucky, but I'm not surprised considering Sony's weird driver design. So keep that in mind.Update:New pair I got does not have the problem I was talking about previously, although I think there might be some channel imbalance??? I think that's just me not being used to more open-ish sound though so don't take my word for it. The manufacturing on theses special drivers are definately going to be a point of contention for buying these. These fit my use case perfectly so it's not a problem but you might weigh your needs differently. These won't be you'd go-to earbuds for sure, you need a good use case for these.

reviewTitle: Great for people who need this type of earbud
reviewDescription: I have had these for a few months and have been really impressed with them. I have ran, bicycled and used them in a motorcycle helmet. They sound pretty good considering they are designed to not be noise cancelling which is why I bought them, I always got this odd sensation when running with noise cancelling earbuds where it seems like the impact of my feet echoed through my head. Running they are almost perfect. The music sounds good and I can still hear the environment and they are comfortable. I wish they stayed in place a bit better. Cycling they are good at normal speeds. when I am going down a hill I can hardly hear the music over the wind noise. I am okay with that because for the majority of the time I can hear them just fine. I also us them in a motorcycle helmet on my commutes. A bit tricky to get the helmet on without knocking a bud out. You can even change the tracks and pause the music with you tap on the helmet. My only cons is I wish you could adjust the volume without going to the phone and the ear wings could be a better. I find they wiggle out when active.  I highly recommend these earbuds.

reviewTitle: They are good for their very specific purpose, not so much for general use.
reviewDescription: So these headphones are designed to help you hear what is going on around you while wearing them, they are awesome in this regard. If you don't need this specific function however there are better cheaper models that do alot better.If you do go this route know these things, you need to play with all the settings they give you, they are highly configurable and they need to be to get them good, they are also not the easiest to put in, once they are perfectly in place however they disappear, you dont even feel them, but you will fiddle with them for a minute to get them into this perfect position.Also know that all the features and stuff that make these awesome also subtract from their battery life, so be aware of that.

This is perfect for listening music at work. You can still hear your colleagues. The microphone is excellent for phone calls. The sound quality is ok. Minus one star as it will not fit every ears. Bought one pair for my wife and she got not get them in her ears.

reviewTitle: Great ear fit and good sound! Also keeps me aware of surroundings.
reviewDescription: These are specifically NOT made for noise cancelling so why mention that like it’s a strike against the product? I bought these so I could use them and still be aware of sound’s around me so I don’t get snuck up on or startled. For this, good sound and the first good ear fit I’ve had? Great job!

Sadly super huge in my petite size ears :( even with the xsmall ring it still hurt after a couple of minutes wearing them. They stay in place no matter what you do, very impressive! I'll keep trying to get use to them by wearing them every day a little longer each time because the sound quality is so great !! 10 out of 10 for the sound, and you can still hear the others around you. Fingers crossed my ears won't hurt in a matter of days.

reviewTitle: A safe alternative to earbuds for runners and cyclists.
reviewDescription: While I appreciate listening to music and podcasts on long runs, I tend not to use headphones as I am uncomfortable with the isolation earbuds provide, and find earbuds often make a booming noise due to bone conduction.I have used the Bose Sport Open Earbuds in the past with good results, and when Sony came out with their take I decided to give them a try. Here’s my opinion on the Sony units. Your mileage may vary.The Sony LinkBuds are small and light, and fit easily in your ear. The different sized stability loops ensure a proper fit. And a proper fit is essential to keep these in your ear and to dial in the sound. With the wrong sized loop, these sound thin and harsh and will pop out of your head. Experiment with the right sized loop for your ear, and the buds will feel locked in, and the sound will be acceptable.I hesitate to talk about the sound, as each of us has different requirements. I was not looking for hifi sound, just a pleasing sound that allowed me to listen to music while letting in ambient sound. The LinkBuds, once I had experimented with fit, met my needs perfectly. If you are bass-head, move on, as you cannot get booming bass out of an open backed earbud.One feature I thought I would love was the speech feature, which cuts the sound when you speak. This worked well on most days, but I find wind will trigger it, so I turn that feature off on very windy days (Which is basically every day on PEI.).I tested the LinkBuds with my iPhone XS, and the app worked flawlessly. I don’t run with my phone, and while I could use the LinkBuds on my older iPod, the app would not load, so functions were more limited.The charging case is tiny and provides an internal battery. I like how the earbuds snap into the case with a satisfying click. I also run with PowerBeats, and have found I often don’t get a correct fit in the case resulting in a dead earbud.Will these replace the Bose? No, as I prefer the warm, tubey Bose signature sound. But I do find the LinkBuds perform better in wind, and do not interfere with the googles I often have to wear in the winter. They each have their advantages, and I will use both happily. If I had to pick one pair, it would be the Bose, but I don’t think Bose is still selling these anymore. They cost the same.Hope that helps, and I wish you all miles of smiles, safely aware of your surroundings.

reviewTitle: Comprehensive Review Update: Sony Linkbuds - An Unparalleled Open-Ear Experience
reviewDescription: Introduction:After a year of continuous use, I wanted to update my review of the Sony Linkbuds. These open-ear earphones have proven to be an exceptional investment, delivering outstanding performance in various scenarios. From seamless communication in work environments to immersive media consumption, these earbuds have consistently impressed me. In this updated review, I will merge my previous thoughts with new insights to provide a comprehensive overview of the Sony Linkbuds.Design and Comfort:The Sony Linkbuds continue to offer excellent comfort, allowing me to wear them for extended periods without any discomfort. The open-ear design serves its purpose flawlessly, enabling easy communication while wearing gloves. Although not suitable for everyone, those in search of this specific feature will appreciate the design. The fit remains secure, ensuring a hassle-free listening experience during media consumption, music playback, and video calls.Sound Quality and Performance:The sound quality of the Sony Linkbuds continues to impress in every aspect. Whether I'm enjoying music, watching videos, or engaging in phone calls, the audio output is consistently remarkable. The balanced sound signature ensures a pleasing experience, with rich bass, clear mids, and vibrant highs. However, it is important to note that the performance of the built-in microphone may be affected in windy or noisy environments, resulting in reduced clarity during calls.Battery Life and Connectivity:Over the past year, the battery life of the Sony Linkbuds has remained reliable. On average, I consistently achieve around 6 hours of playback time before receiving a low battery notification. This duration allows for extended usage without worrying about frequent recharging. The Bluetooth connectivity remains stable, ensuring a seamless connection with my devices. Pairing is effortless, and once connected, the earbuds maintain a consistent and reliable connection.Pros (Unchanged):1. Exceptional audio quality for media consumption, music, and calls.2. Comfortable design ideal for extended use.3. Open-ear design facilitates easy communication while wearing gloves.4. Reliable battery life with low battery notifications.5. Stable Bluetooth connectivity.Cons (Updated):1. Not suitable for everyone due to the open-ear design.2. Performance may be affected in windy or noisy environments, impacting call clarity.Conclusion:After a year of continuous use, the Sony Linkbuds have proven to be the best earphones I have ever purchased. They excel in providing an unparalleled open-ear experience, allowing for seamless communication in work environments while delivering exceptional sound quality for media consumption and calls. The comfortable design, reliable battery life, and stable connectivity make these earbuds a reliable and enjoyable companion. However, it is important to note that in windy or noisy environments, the performance of the built-in microphone may be affected. If you are in search of open-ear earphones and prioritize exceptional audio performance, the Sony Linkbuds are an investment that will continue to satisfy your needs.

reviewTitle: A year later and I’d add a star if I could.
reviewDescription: One year on and these buds are incredible. Everything I said before still applies. In fact I’m seriously considering buying another pair to keep in a drawer just in case I lose one or both of these.Here’s my original review:I was nervous about buying these. I'd tried open earbuds made by the other guys and while the sound was great, the design was awful. They hurt my ears, were impossible to wear with glasses and made every workout painful. I'd tried bone conduction headphones, but the cheap ones sounded awful and the most expensive set made my entire head vibrate if you turned the volume up even slightly. The sound was also quite muffled.So would it be third time lucky? I read the reviews and the fact that some people complained about the lack of bass with the Sony Linkbuds made me even more nervous. But when they arrived, I literally could not believe my ears.These buds sound absolutely amazing. There's plenty bass for me, and the sound is clear. I don't know how to explain this other than to say that it sounds "clean". Every note is crystal clear. I actually want to work out more often because my music sounds so good.Also, the wide area tap is terrific. It works instantly. With all my old wireless earphones, there's been a slight delay when skipping to the next song. It's never bothered me, but with the Linkbuds, you tap three times and your new song starts instantly. That's so much better.They also stay in my ears perfectly, even when I stand up on the bike and push hard. I've done a 2 hour indoor ride and they were comfortable throughout. No irritation, no itching, no pain. In fact, it's easy to forget that you're even wearing them, and not listening to your music out loud.Thank you Sony! You really did get these right.

reviewTitle: Best in class in a very specific niche.
reviewDescription: Basically, are you already someone who uses your earbuds in transparency mode 70%+ of the time? If so, get Linkbuds.My shipment got lost, so I got a refund (no hassle!) and then bought them at a brick an mortar store in March 2022. But apparently I still get to review these, so here we go.My coworkers have a surprisingly large vocal range, and the transparency mode on the Galaxy Buds+ I used previously just randomly wouldn't pick up some of my coworkers. I was already listening to music at work with transparency mode enabled 100% of the time, so switching to the Linkbuds was a zero friction changeover. It's not perfectly transparent - sound is very slightly muffled - but it's way more range accurate and won't randomly mute or amplify things.On the other hand, if you try to use while walking downtown at rush hour, or on a moving train or something, they'll be completely overpowered by the ambient noise and you'll barely be able to hear anything, even if you crank the volume. They'll still manage if you're standing in line at a store, which isn't amazing but again you're buying these so you can eventually hear the cashier when you're next.Default flat EQ is awful, and the presets are also pretty bad. I've attached my preferred EQ, which is pretty different from the current top review, so maybe that'll help someone else out. I'm not an audiophile, but this seems to work for me as, "I can hear everything in a track while sitting in a quiet room without anything sounding overpowering or distorted."Battery life vs. Buds+ with transparency constantly enabled...is still noticeably worse. 5-5.5 hrs is spot on, so you'll need to find time to throw these back into their case for a few minutes during a typical 8-hour shift. Having said that, Buds+ with constant transparency was just barely crapping out around the end of my shift, so I had to find time to charge those anyways.Fitting these in your ear has a learning curve. Essentially, put the donut in your ear canal, then push the plastic bits downwards until they stop (at the bottom of your concha). The correct adjustment hoop should just barely provide a third point of pressure once you've done this, and then it should stay in place. I have noticed that wide yawning can dislodge the buds, though.

This is a specific use headset not jack of all trades. If you need open ear buds to use in office or calls its excellent. I use in meetings talking while working and in fields. Call quality it top tier. Talking to my wife while out. Its great talking headset or to listen to podcasts while still listen to surrounding. That said you have to use both. The 360 makes it clear. I find when using one headset you cranking the volume too high and not as clear. The spacial awareness when 2 earbuds in is key. I would not use to listen to music. It fit my specific need perfectly which is to talk one specialist privately while giving out comands on people onsite.

Unlike other quality ear buds, these do not go into the ear canal.  It takes a short while to get used to them and then they are great.  I find that they stay in the ear well and don't pop out like my old ear buds did.  I highly recommend these if you're looking for something that does not go into the ear canal.  I also tried Shokz open fit but they did not work for me as they were not tight against the ear.

reviewTitle: Slender fit, could sleep with them in.  Great once you learn them.
reviewDescription: If you are looking for bass you probably already know these won't be the best. They sit over your ear canal and allow sound to enter.  I was on the fence how well the open back concept would work and the outside world sounds mixed with audio was perfect.  The audio quality does go hand in hand with the quality of audio compression and the settings.Battery life was decent.  I dont need an all day earbud personally but they last for my required 2hrs or so at a time that I do.  Now the comfort.  I use the large wing to keep some pressure of the ear piece but after a few times the minor pain after wearing for extended periods went away.  With  the large wing and in my ear properly,  I could not shake out the buds no matter how hard I tried.They have a niche market usage, but for walking around the house and light music listening,  perfect.  I've even used them while driving on low volume...you know when you got grandma in the car and she hates the stereo but still wants to talk...I set the sound to maybe a third and I can carry conversation just like I'm next to a stereo booming.

reviewTitle: Fantastic alternative to bone conduction headphones
reviewDescription: I needed an option for music and podcast listening that still enabled some level of awareness to my outside environment. Ideally for use during running or hiking. I tried the Shokz Openmove Pro which were a decent option but the sound quality was clearly a compromise. They sounded tinny and anemic which was clearly a trade off for not having earbuds stuffed in your ears and allowing sound in.Enter the Sony linkbuds. These are infinitely better for the same use and application plus the sound quality is competitive with actual in-ear earbuds in the comparable price range. The ear canal is left open so external sound is still audible but music is layered on top so you are not devoid of activity in your immediate surroundings. My only real gripe are these are so incredibly light so they may feel a bit cheap? The case is also extremely small and bare bones and lacks the quality you would expect from something more weighted and substantial. On the contrary this could be seen as a testament to how much thought and development went into these to streamline the design and omit anything not crucial to performance. On the whole, I have to commend Sony for being environmentally conscious and minimizing this product’s footprint.

reviewTitle: I really wanted to love these
reviewDescription: When I first saw these I knew I had to get them for their key features of allowing ambient sound in and the buds not going into the ear canal.In particular to my ear shape and size, the buds press against the antihelux in my ear which really starts to hurt after prolonged wear. I think perhaps it's because I have smaller ears than who these were designed for, which is very unfortunate as these buds tick every other box aside from comfort.While not a deal-breaker for me personally as I use these mostly for voice calls, I had to disable the tap features as my hair kept accidentally triggering it somehow (I have long hair that covers my ears). I didn't test this too much, but it was annoying to hear random beeping from having the tap feature triggered.If your ears are on the smaller side or have long hair that you don't like to tie up, I would not recommend this product unless you are able to try it on and test beforehand. All else, as other reviews have stated, sound and functionality are superb.

This isn't much of a review but more of a fix for people that aren't happy with the sound out of the box. First make sure DSEE is turned on it smoothes things out a bit, out of the box the blue tooth is set to prioritize connection so make sure that's switched to sound quality, and finally take advantage of eq, all sony products heavily utilize this out of the box but it seems sony hasn't applied  any heavy eq out of the box for the link buds so it sounds like the xm3 headphones when there not powered on. I've included my custom eq settings that I'm happy with, to me it makes them sound like a mini version of the xm3 headphones but with less low end obviously.

I have used many pairs of truly wireless earbuds since they've became available.The most recent pair I had were the Galaxy Buds 2Pro. Those headphones had great sound but I really struggled to get them seated in my ears properly where I'd pass a fit test regardless of the ear tip ( I tried all 3 sizes) and they would fall out during any activity. Even walking I would have to constantly push them in and it was annoying at it would register as a tap or hold and modify the media I was listening to.These Pixel Bud Pros fit perfectly! They are very easy to insert and seal in your ear. They offer great noise isolation due to their snug fit and design and even better noise cancellation when enabled. I am able to go on runs and workout without having to adjust the placement and I don't have to worry about them falling out.The Pixel Buds Pro provide a premium audio experience that is immersive, detailed, and well-balanced across the frequency spectrum. They offer a rich and deep bass response that adds depth and punch to music genres like hip-hop and EDM. The bass is tight and controlled, without overpowering the other frequencies. The midrange is clean and precise, allowing vocals and instruments to shine through with clarity. The treble is crisp and extends well, offering a delightful sparkle to the overall sound signature.What sets the Pixel Buds Pro apart is the ability to customize the audio experience through EQ adjustments. The companion app allows you to fine-tune the sound to your personal preference. Whether you prefer a bass-heavy sound or a more neutral, balanced output, the EQ adjustments give you the flexibility to tailor the audio to your liking.

reviewTitle: Clear audio but short for battery life
reviewDescription: These buds fit fine in the ear but you need to ensure you use the right rubber ear pieces provided so that they fit and sit well in the ear. I find the battery life rather short in comparison to my JBL's. The audio for the Pixel Buds Pro is fantastic. The audio is clear, clean, and has nice EQ adjustments to fine tune to your taste. I love these ear buds especially for calls as they are nice and crisp for someone hard of hearing like me. No regrets but hoping they improve battery life.

reviewTitle: Amazing Ear Buds but Apple still takes the league in many areas
reviewDescription: The Pixel Buds Pro are absolutely amazing. Great sound, best battery life, great features, great case, good seal, etc.That being said, full disclosure, there's just some things competitors do better.The competitors I'm about to mention are ALSO 5 out of 5 headphones, I refuse to duck a point "because some do some stuff slightly better". They are still completely fine and an awesome product but.If you want ANC where noises get muffled when you DON'T play music, Bose Quietcomfort are still better. The ANC is actually weaker than Apple's Airpods pro and SONY WF-1000XM4.If you want the best music, Beyerdynamic's Free Byrd crushes this.If you want the best value, as premium ear buds, this isn't it. Get some Jabra Elite 3s.If you want the best gym buds, you get some cheap chinese crap because EVENTUALLY even with IP X4, sweat will destroy them. If you insist on spending more, Beats Powerbeats Pro. You NEED the hook around the ear. Unless you're not serious about working out.If you want the best mics, you can't beat Airpods pro, the mic is at the bottom of the stick and closer to your mouth.So why is this 5/5?Well it's a SUPER solid jack-of-all trades.Best battery life, way above average case, way above average sound, way above average connectivity, way above average everything to be frank. It's subtle too and doesn't stick out too much.Also the pixel buds interact SUPER well with my Pixel phone to give me LIVE translations in my ear. This is a GAME CHANGER for anyone travelling.
Excellent sound quality. Comfortable to wear. Intelligent enough to stop playing music when I speak. Highly recommended.
Everything works as it's intended too. The noise cancelling feature is fantastic and they have great sound. They pair easily with multiple devices and it's easy to switch between the paired devices.

I think these little fellows are particularly good. The music plays well (although I've already seen better, but seriously they still deserve a good 4 out of 5). The noise canceling is excellent (even too much sometimes) and I like the transparency mode which is automatically activated when it detects that I am talking to someone (except when I blow my nose as it thinks that I am talking to someone). Overall, very satisfied and I recommend without hesitation.
Maintenant plusieurs mois que je l'utilise et je n'ai aucun problème majeur seulement un bug de connexion 2 fois mais rien de grave

reviewTitle: It 's a Googe product so it doesn't dissappoint
reviewDescription: Other than Google being Google and saving your data, this noise cancelling ear buds are the most effective buds I've experienced. My spouse bought them for me and swears by the hear-ability when I speak to her compared most other comparable devices on the market.I would recommend to a friend.

As all google product, You really can't go wrong. They have a beautiful sound. Calls are crisp and clear. I just wish the battery last longer. I often have to switch them midday to recharge. Not a huge deal.

I took great care of them, always kept them clean and in a case. After just 1 year and 3 weeks (just enough for the 1 year warranty to run out) the left earbud bud stopped working. To be specific, it stopped charging while the charging case started to act up. Reached out to Google support, and honestly so far the experience was very disappointing. I've owned every pixel from pixel 3 with the exception of pixel 6... And honestly it's making it very hard to trust their build quality. All of my phones had to be either replaced multiple times or repaired. Again, I take good care of my electrons and in general of any items. I now own a pixel watch 2 and while smooth it's built quality I'd also questionable... The screen is something else for a $500 watch lol [Sarcasm]. I don't understand why the build quality can't be improved and the lack of support is kinda strange to say the least. Funny enough, I thought of a adding a picture of them on here... But they look brand new so you couldn't even tell that they no longer work 😅.

Around 2 months after the date of purchase, the left bud began to produce a clicking noise while ANC was on. The warrant was still valid, so I contacted Google support to have them replaced or repaired. The outsourced Google agent I spoke with went through every single troubleshooting method before he sent me a warranty form. Some of the actions he made me take were completely unreasonable, like pairing the buds to another device to see if the issue persists. The cherry onto however was in the terms of the warranty form, which state that if Google deems the issue as being caused by something not covered in the warranty, I will be charged the FULL RETAIL VALUE for the replacement. After the hoops support made me go through just to access the warranty form, I decided not to send my Pixel Buds in for repair. fast forward 2 months and both earbuds are barely audible even with the media volume on my phone turned all the way up. I would expect this type of customer service from a cheap, unknown company, but not from the richest company in the world.

Quickly developed a intermittent squeal in the right ear bud that happens every thirty seconds or so. Customer service consisted of them recommending me send them in and they will send me a refurbished used pair. Is it just me, or is wearing a strangers used ear buds equivalent to wearing a stranger's used underwear. Disgusting.
They are quiet, read up on this online. The phone has to be full blast. I have a pizlxel 7 pro. Also tried with Samsung tablet and same deal. For almost 200 these are a joke. Returning them.

reviewTitle: Loose fit....PLEASE DONT BUY Had to return these
reviewDescription: I've been waiting for pro ear buds from google for a long time(maybe more than 3 years because i like using google products) and I'm disappointed after ordering them. I ordered them in sept 2022 when they were released and had to return them coz they dont fint properly in my ears and everytime i go out for a walk they would just fall off on the road 🤦 and the comply memory foam ear tips were not available when I ordered them in September. Now in January 2023 I ordered them again with comply ear tips so that they would fit properly. Even with the comply ear dips they don't fit in my ears. Even when I sat at my table and having lunch they would just fell off of my ears and i tried all the different sizes of ear tips. Please dont buy these because fit and confort is the most important for ear buds.

reviewTitle: If you lose an earbud or a case you cannot buy spares, you have to buy a whole new set.
reviewDescription: Lost my case and found out the earbuds were useless because Google won't sell you a spare part. The only way to charge earbuds is with the case. If I lived in America Google might sell me spare parts but not here in Canada. These are small pieces, you will likely lose one of them over time. Obviously Google has lots of parts but this is a choice they have made that suits their bottom line but not your bottom line.

This review is no reflection on the product as I did not have the opportunity to try them.Recieved a brand new pair of buds pro to discover the seal was broken. Charging case had dirt stains on it and the buds themselves had ear wax on them.No level of compensation offered and now I have the hassle of returning them. Incredibly disappointed.

The product that arrived looked legit, but was opened and not sealed. When I turned them on, the earbuds were already named "Ray's ear buds"  and previously connected to an account. Will be returning and refunding.
JE SUIS ENTREPRENEUR EN RÉNO ET LES BUDS NE TIENT PAS DANS L'OREILLE
Pass by anyone else wearing bluetooth headphones? Sit on a bus, train or plane? Prepare to have your sound cut out. Absolutely unbearable.

I had a pair of Pixel Buds for a while and I was generally happy with them.  When I broke one, I decided to upgrade to the Pro.  I hate the new design! I really liked the way my old pair fit with the stabilizing fins!These don’t have the stabilizing fins and guess what? They are not stable.  I can no longer do housework, jog, or just look down at something before these things fall out of my ears.  I tried the different sizes of ear thingies, but none of the sizes stopped them from falling out when I do anything.This really sucks and I regret buying them, I let it go too long I should have returned them.  When I was doing dishes one almost fell in the dishwater and I had to warn people off.  It gets 3 stars though because the Pro’s battery life is really impressive compared to the regular Buds, and the noise cancelling is very handy when I’m on voice call every day.If Google hadn’t got rid of the fins, these would be the best earbuds out there IMO.  So disappointed.

reviewTitle: Good sound, and buds have advertised battery life.
reviewDescription: However, the description says that including the case, you get up to 31 hours without ANC/20 with ANC, which is extremely misleading.In reality, the case adds around 13 hours of battery life with ANC. Of course, the advertisement is technically not wrong if you start off with fully charged earbuds that will last 7 hours, but it misleads you to think the case adds another 20 hours, which is not true.Sound quality:There's a lot of bass.The sound quality is good, which is all I can say. Obviously an open-back headphone like the SHP9500 sounds a lot better, but it doesn't sound bad. In fact, I like the sound quality better than the bose qc35ii.  It's a lot better than any wireless earbud or earphone you can buy for under 50 dollars, that I can say for sure. (However, there are wired iems under 50 that sound better).Also, I've noticed there's like a 1/4th second sound output delay, which feels awkward. So it's not ideal for playing games.Bluetooth connectivity:The Bluetooth is the best out of any Bluetooth device I've used. For example, Sennheiser 4.50btnc, bose qc 35ii, TWS earbuds. Pretty much, if you are within 2 meters of the device, even if you are in a very crowded space, it won't disconnect. It will briefly disconnect maybe once or twice over a span of 5 hours, which is very acceptable. In a less crowded space, it will remain connected within 8 meters. In your house, if no one else is using Bluetooth, you can pretty much walk anywhere while connected. Unlike the bose qc 35ii and Sennheiser 4.50btnc which start disconnecting as soon as I walk out of the room.ANC:The ANC is worse than the bose headphones, and I believe comparable to the airpods pro. It will completely cancel out any air conditioning noise. It will partially cancel out car engine noises, but will not cancel out any car horns.Comfort:If 10/10 is you feel nothing in your ears, it's probably around a 5/10.If 7/10 is you wearing foam earplugs, it's around a 9/10.Transparency mode:7/10. It does not sound realistic, but it does what it's supposed to do. However, that's not the reason I gave it a 7/10. The problem is you will hear wind noise blasting when you are just walking around in still air.Touch controls:I don't know why they made triple tap to go to a previous song, why not just make double tap the right earbud to skip forward and double tap the left earbud to go back?I've gotten somewhat used to the touch controls now, and it does what I want it to do 95% of the time. There are some occurrences where I try to turn up or down the volume and it ends up pausing/turning off ANC. But I believe with enough practice, that won't happen.Overall, I would give this at least 4 stars, but I didn't like the way they advertised the battery for the case, so I'm giving it 3 to discourage them from doing that.Update: Oh my goodness. I just tried 80+% volume for the first time and it's horrible. A whole bunch of static noises. (I'm listening to Viva la vida) I am going to return this. My 3/4 star rating is only applicable for people that listen to music below 50%, it sounds terrible above that.

reviewTitle: Great sound quality plagued with software issues.
reviewDescription: So I bought these earbuds after buying a pixel 7 pro thinking that because they're same family of devices that it would work pretty well. Sadly however these earbuds are plagued a whole bunch of issues I believe are software related but almost never get fixed. For starters the earbuds discharge unevenly causing one earbud to have less battery than the other and apparently it's a common issue with these buds. The other glaring issue is that one earbud stops working (usually the right one for me) when making phone calls especially on Whatsapp. I found that other owners also have the same issues and people have submitted tickets directly to Google hoping for a fix but nothing has been made of it yet. One other thing is the call quality/microphone quality (for the person on the other end) is very bad so much so that they can't quite hear me well so I have to disconnect buds and just use the phone. The audio/sound quality is pretty damn good with a nice balance and nice base. The noise cancellation works pretty well too but I wish the ambient mode was better at detecting voices and amplifying it seeing as how good Google is with voice detection. I would sadly not recommend these to anyone who wants to use the full roster of features it come as the only thing it seems to do well is just audio and noise cancelling.

reviewTitle: Good but uncomfortable in the ear.
reviewDescription: Everything is as advertised except the comfort level in the ears is unsatisfactory.I find my ears get really sore after wearing the pods for longer than 30mins. I have to take them out after that time period.

Great sound quality and features. But I have to say that I'm still disappointed. No matter what size ear tip I use, they always end up falling off my ears. When you're walking outside and suddenly one decides to drop off my ear, that's a pretty big fall on the ground. I have them for about 3 months and I rarely use them because of this. It's been probably too long to have a refund anyway.
They don't have a search system like airpods, I already lost two

reviewTitle: May not seal on some era canals
reviewDescription: No issues with all the features, liked that the buds and case a very small. The only issue was that the no tips would get the seal in my ears. I would get an OK sound if the buds were pushed in deep, but this was from the seal between itself the bud and the ear canal. This would get uncomfortable quickly. Had to return.

reviewTitle: Ok, but will wait for a newer model
reviewDescription: I liked the previous models with ear support, tried all the Silicon provided, not the greatest fit personally, and not for an active lifestyle/exercise/jog, the fit isn't secure.

reviewTitle: Great but the noise cancellation sucks.
reviewDescription: Pro's- really good sound quality I can hear things I couldn't hear on apple pro's- Google assistant is amazing, I love it- controls are awesome, although a manual button would've been nice-comfyCons-anc literally sucks, you can hear most things with them on and is more like a dull effect- phone quality is meh- controls can sometimes conflict with each other because of sensitivityIs it worth the price? Probably not, but they are great and at 200 and lower would be 5/5.
Really well thought. The app is really nice and the ANC is really impressive but...Always felt like they were falling of my ears and the microphone wasn't good in noisy environment, had to return it

I bought these headphones to replace a pair of workout headphones that, over time, needed to be charged more and more frequently. Overall, I love these headphones but there are some (small?) things that annoy me.Pros:- The sound quality is amazing. I've tried several wired and wireless headphones and  there are right up there in terms of sound quality. The base is punchy and there is very little distortion. Other similarly styled headphones that go in the ear tend to seal against the surface of the inner ear which, at least in my case, made it so that I could hear my heartbeat over whatever I was listening to.- The battery life is also great. Much much better than the headphones the buds pro replaced, and seemingly better than other premium brands that my friends have purchased.- The brand and the app are "trusted". At least they are more trusted than other brands out there. Most wireless headphones require that an app be installed. Some of those apps ask for permissions to access things like your financial info and demographics that in my mind, a headphone app should not be asking for.- The buds come with two additional pairs of silicone ear pieces that let you get the perfect fit.- Pairing was a breeze. I have a Samsung S22 Ultra and as soon as I opened the case, a message popped up on my phone to start the pairing process (which took about 2 minutes to complete).Cons:- The headphones aren't as loud as others I have tried. While noise cancelation does a good job of filtering out the noise so that you can hear your music clearly, the volume could be louder.- The app is fairly rudimentary. There is no EQ function (yet) so you can't tweak the sound to your preference.- The headphones do wiggle themselves loose at times. Pushing them back in the ear does activate the touch controls which is a bit annoying.

They're really nice earbuds and very great sound quality! My only complaint is the touch area is essentially the entire outer bud, so if you're trying to adjust it or just take one out you tend to hit buttons essentially. Very small annoyance overall compared to the great sound they produce! They're also very comfortable to wear!

reviewTitle: Great sound, difficult for for small ears
reviewDescription: These are easy to use and have great sound, and they do come with three different ear buds sizes, but unfortunately even the smallest size is a not a good fit for my small ears. I still use them, but if I were to go for a run they would come loose and fall out. Over the ear headphones will still be my go-to for this reason.

These headphones are almost perfect, I use them in the gym, for work, running, and almost all the time.I also have a Bose nc700 but this actually has a better noise cancellation.The only problem is that it gets too hot in my ear to the point that it gets annoying.

I own the Pixel serie A earbuds and I love it.Everything about the Pro is better.... sometimes, WAY better!I wear my earbuds and headphones a lot  Way to much.Since I bought the Pixel pro, I have been dealing with a sore ear.Maybe it's just a coincidence.I sure hope so.I recommend this product nonetheless.

I'm an Android user (though Samsung) so when my last earbuds died in a JetSki accident I splurged and picked these up. Sound quality is good and the ANC is much better than my previous Nothing ear(1)s (but it should be for the 2x price). Comfort is okay at best though. Since these are the 'twist in' style fit is very subjective. I don't have quite the problems of looseness or discomfort that some do but they definitely take more effort to put in than the 'hanging' style Apple Pro knockoff buds. Once they're in they're fine though and for me make a good seal.  At this price range there's lots of options and probably better buds but in general I'm pretty happy with them.

reviewTitle: Worth it if you catch them on sale
reviewDescription: Noise cancelling is alright, sound quality is pretty good, battery life is excellent, ease of pairing is fantastic (I have a pixel phone). I am glad I didn't pay full price for these because they aren't exactly perfect but I'm really happy with them and they are a huge upgrade from my previous wireless earbuds which were losing battery life rapidly.
My only issue is that they fall out when I work out.

reviewTitle: son los mejores que he probado
reviewDescription: por el precio no esperaba menos todo va perfectomi única queja es que cuando lo tienes emparejado a más de un dispositivo a la vez a veces lo que estás escuchando se puede entrecortar un poco, pero apagando este modo todo perfecto.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2023
reviewDescription: Update: I took these out to one of the many circles of heck known as “Mid-Morning Grocery Shopping on a Sunday” (meaning, it's far too busy, and crowded for comfort). I have to say, the experience was much better than that of the AirPods Pro (APP). When I walked, I never got that low “thump” in my ears like with the APP, they felt secure, and I didn't need to adjust them after initially inserting them. The best part? Zero pain/pressure after removing them.Using these with a Pixel 8 Pro. The case is very nice and has a matte finish, so it should hide micro-scratches better than the AirPods cases. USB-C, plus wireless charging (Qi).The earbuds themselves are small, and round. This makes them a little difficult to remove from the case, and hold with 2 fingers securely. Inserting the earbuds is equally challenging, since there is no wing to brace against your ear's Concha (The wing exists on the cheaper Pixel Buds A, but not the “Pro” for some reason). Therefore, the earbud might be rotated at an angle that blocks part of a microphone. In my initial testing, I didn't notice this affect the Active Noise Cancelling (ANC).I have tiny ear canals, and therefor need special ear-tips that are smaller than “Small”. Thankfully, my favorite tip maker, Spinfit sells a kit that allows me to use size SS tips (seen in my photos). CP1025 with CPA2 is the kit if anyone wants to try them. Spinfit are the only after-market tips I use on all my IEMs. Well worth the price.The version out of the box for the case, and buds was 1.5. If you happen to read this, do yourself a favor and update the firmware ASAP. Now on version 5.9 (I think), and not only does the default tuning sound better, they added numerous new features, including a customizable EQ*.Going back to the shape, the side of the earbuds (where the color is, and the “G” logo) is one big touch-surface. This is the only method to control the sound when your phone/source is unreachable. This is active as soon as the buds are out of the case, and connected. Inserting them in a secure position will cause your media to play, pause, skip a track or two, call the Assistant, raise/lower the volume. So when you finally have them inserted, it's a gamble as to what will be playing at what volume.They sound good with the new firmware, and can be used for all kinds of music. You might not get the Honda Civic trunk-shaking bass you want, but that is where the EQ comes in. Turn up the “Low bass” slider, and you'll hear it. Max out the bass, and low bass sliders, and you'll get a similar tuning to Raycons if that's your thing (Don't buy Raycons). The ANC is nice. Not thrilling, but nice. I've been spoiled by Sony's ANC. I'd imagine these would work on a commercial plane to drown out the cabin rumble enough to listen to music at a reasonable level. The transparency mode is usable, but doesn't come anywhere close to Apple's version, where it sounds 99% natural. This can always be fixed with firmware updates.I still need some more time with these to decide whether the weird fit is something I can live with or not.*The EQ is very user-friendly, but a little maddening for anyone who uses a multi-band equalizer. None of the frequencies are labeled. Instead, they opt for “friendly” names. Upper Treble, Treble, Mid, Bass, and Low Bass. It's hard to get a good EQ with these options, since I know what frequencies I normally add/subtract to. I'm not sure if the friendly names are a single frequency, or a group. I have a feeling they are a group of frequencies, since “Mid” can consist of 8 or more bands, and bass is usually 4–6 bands. It's better than nothing, though, and shockingly, these buds can do a little sub-bass.

reviewTitle: Beware - known bug with Samsung phones that Google hasn't done anything about
reviewDescription: First, let me say these buds may be great for many people, which is the only reason I gave them a 2 star review and not a 1 star review.Everything on these works pretty much as expected- the noise canceling, sound, etc is great. And I LOVE the ability to use google assistant with them.HOWEVER, and here's the deal breaker, if you have a Samsung phone, there's a very well-known glitch that Google hasn't fixed in more than a year.If you make or receive phone calls with these on a Samsung phone, sometimes both buds work for a short while, but the left one will drop off, if it even works to begin with. The only way to get it to work again is to put it back in the case, close the case, then remove it again. Then it'll disconnect again a coupe of minutes later.Like I said, this is extremely well known with thousands of complaints- just google "pixel buds pro phone calls only working in one bud"If you don't intend to use these for phone calls, go ahead. But if you have a Samsung phone and want to make phone calls, avoid these. I'm sending them back, and I really wish I would have known about this beforehand.

They fall out, are a little uncomfortable and sometimes drop calls for a few seconds. The main thing I hate about them is they fall out when you eat and sometimes for no reason. The sound cancelling is cool. The touch controls are weird and it's hard to use and sometimes when I'm adjusting them in my ear I hang up or skip a song. All and all not worth the money. I would go with head phones over ear buds if I had to do it again.
They work fantastically. The only thing I don't like is that they don't stay in the ear. They fall many times and I have been closed to step on them or even to lose them in the sewere.
Was very hard to connect. Had to reset buds . The one side was crackling.  And there was hardly any volume .
The XM4 is better in every regard... Wish I didn't buy this

reviewTitle: Things no one tells you about these earbuds
reviewDescription: These earbuds have some major issues that i feel compelled to share. its a common issue that they do not fit ears tightly and will fall out. i had to do a grip tape sticker mod to them to make them stay in my ears.the next thing is the charging contacts are placed close to your skin so they get oily and need to be cleaned regularly. they stop the earphones from disconnecting from your phone because they do not sense them being connected and charging because the dirt and oil are in the way. my third issue is with googles customer service. they do not stand behind there products. i brought all my concerns to them and was promptly ignored. i also find them very quiet compared to other headphones ive had. i removed the speaker grills which helped a little bit. my recommendation. just pay the extra and get the airpods pro. at least apple will stand behind them and you dont have to do modifications to them to get the performance out of them.

reviewTitle: NOT for music - poor sound quality and then some
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2023
reviewDescription: Do you like high-quality sound ? Then do NOT buy these- they make music sound very muddy and muffled. Maybe if you're used to blasting tunes through the smartphone speakers, this could be considered an upgrade in quality, but otherwise no. I ended up returning these and buying Anker Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro and the difference in sound quality couldn't be any more drastic- even without using LDAC codec (pixel buds Pro only support AAC- more on that later).  It was like going from FM radio to a CD. Anyway, this isn't a review of Anker, so moving on...Overall, pixel buds Pro are a massive letdown with half baked design/engineering, and worst of all- VERY poor sound quality. A beta product at best (at least some consistency here from Google and its Beta Universe of Beta Everything). If you're mainly using them for zoom or voice calls, listening to podcasts, etc they might do the trick, but so will a $50 set of buds. But if you intend to use them for listening to music, they simply don't deliver- certainly not for a hefty $150-200 price tag.No amount of EQ tweaking could bring any quality/clarity to the music, albeit the available EQ settings are very rudimentary- just the 5 fixed frequency "sliders" (but without actual frequencies/Hz even being indicated) plus a handful of presets.The EQ and other controls worked very well on a Pixel phone as did the Bluetooth pairing- a really slick pairing experience, actually. However, when I tried installing the Pixel Buds app on a NON-Pixel Android 13 phone, it didn't show any of the controls (the app basically didn't work), so YMMV on any device that's not a Google's own phone.The other downside to the app is the very limited configuration options and settings for customizing the touch controls- can not adjust touch sensitivity or just simply disable the touch function (the buds constantly register "touch" when they're merely being adjusted and perform random actions as a result).After a couple of days playing with these, I noticed the buds' batteries will drain from just sitting. There is no way to actually turn them off other than by returning into the charging case and closing it (triple tap no longer works). Seriously, Google- a $200 headphone set that is too dumb to not turn itself off when not in use! Or is it too "Apple" for you to actually have the buds turn off automatically when they're removed from one's ears, especially considering that all necessary sensors and HW are already there anyway and the headphones "know" when they're inserted and removed? At least offer a configurable sleep timer/power save mode- like virtually every gadget on the planet has.Speaking of Apples, while the buds- ostensibly designed for Pixel and Android phones- support Apple's (defacto) AAC codec of all things(!), they lack support for any higher quality codecs, such as Qualcomm Apt-x, Aptx-LL, or Sony's LDAC. If I wanted headphones that are "married" to Apple and its AAC, I might've as well bought Airpods Pro or Bose...As there is no way to adjust touch sensitivity or disable the touch function, the buds end up doing random things (play, skip, toggling ANC) while I'm simply adjusting them for better fit. Perhaps on/off functionality would be helpful here too, so that I may first adjust the fit before actually turning them on. And seeing how they automatically turn on when removed from the case, this becomes yet another source of battery drain, should I for whatever reason just put them aside. To avoid battery drain they must be returned to the case every time- no alternatives here. Seems like Apple's "philosophy", i.e. "we've already decided what's best for you and how you should use your device, so we won't give you any options". Again, if I wanted the vendor dictate how I use my devices, I might as well buy Apple products... Don't we all use Google/Android products because they allow(ed) flexibility instead of forcing the user into doing  things as the vendor decided is the "best" (and the only) way ?Fit- while this is subjective, I could never get them to fit securely, despite trying different size ear tips (hence the need for adjustments which wreaked havoc with the touch interface). The buds always felt somewhat loose, albeit that loose fit made them comfortable to wear for hours without any strain or pressure on the ears- guess this is the silver lining. But forget trying to run or exercise in these. The lack of wingtips is probably the biggest issue with the design to ensure a secure fit.The only other thing I liked about these buds besides their "loose-fitting" wearing comfort is the ANC- it did a very good job drowning out the sound of rushing water and other background noises. So they get 1 star for comfort and one star for ANC.

reviewTitle: I want to like them ( pixel super fan)
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2023
reviewDescription: As a pixel user I truly wanted this to work, I wanted to love them but I find myself wanting something else. These buds sound great when they work, noise canceling is excellent, transparent mode is good.My issue is they are ALWAYS CONNECTED, even when you put them back in the case they always connect to the phone and this isn’t just exclusive to pixel, I’ve tested on Samsung and iPhone and they do the same thing. This is supper annoying especially when you are trying to hear a video or even take a phone call and they connect without you knowing. I wouldn’t recommend them at this price, $100 would be solid even $115 but nothing more, it’s so many other options that don’t have this problem, I find myself just turning Bluetooth off on my phone so I know it won’t connect. I’ve had them for over a year and they’ve had the issue the entire time, I dealt with it hoping google correct the issue with an update but no…. They haven’t fixed anything, as a super fan this is disappointing, I find myself feeling like google doesn’t care and I shouldn’t be spending my money on half baked products. If this issue wasn’t a thing I would give it 4.5, the other issue is they fall out, I know that’s a personal issue but I’ve never had buds that fell out this often ( look into better tips) I would avoid getting them at $200 , not worth that price.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2023
reviewDescription: These headphones are just ridiculously finicky, even when using them with a Pixel phone.
